Chapters.Title: 96  CHAPTER
Text:
of Basic Education 2014
96  CHAPTER 4 ECONOMIC GEOGRAPHY OF SOUTH AFRICA 
Mind the Gap CAPS Grade 12 Geography
Chapter
4
Follow the steps to read 
the graph
1. The heading â the graph shows GDP (factor 1) in relation to 
different provinces (factor 2).
2. The sectors (pieces or slices) of the pie graph show factor 1 â the 
contribution of each province to the GDP. 
3. Units of measurement â the sectors of the pie graph show factor 1 
(GDP) in percentage. 
4. The relationship between the different factors â because a pie 
chart compares parts of a whole, you need to note the different 
sizes of the sectors. This tells you how much each province 
contributes to the total GDP.
5. Look for anything that is unusual â for example, which is the 
largest piece of the pie (Gauteng) and which is the smallest piece 
of the pie (Northern Cape).
6. Now read the questions in activity 4.6.
 Activity 4.6
The following questions refer to Figure 4.5.1B on page 95.
1. Rank the top three provinces in terms of their contribution  
to the GDP from largest to smallest contribution. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
2. Give two reasons why the province ranked first in your  
answer in question 1 holds that position. 
(2 Ã 2 = 4)
3. The following questions refer to the province which  
contributes the least to the national GDP.
a) Name the province which contributes the least to the  
national GDP. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
b) Name the ocean current that flows alongside this  
province. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
c) What impact does this ocean current have on the  
rainfall in this province? 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
d) Explain how your answer in question c) affects the  
provinceâs contribution to the GDP. 
(2 Ã 2 = 4)
[16]

Text:
OGRAPHY OF SOUTH AFRICA 
Mind the Gap CAPS Grade 12 Geography
Chapter
4
Follow the steps to read 
the graph
1. The heading â the graph shows GDP (factor 1) in relation to 
different provinces (factor 2).
2. The sectors (pieces or slices) of the pie graph show factor 1 â the 
contribution of each province to the GDP. 
3. Units of measurement â the sectors of the pie graph show factor 1 
(GDP) in percentage. 
4. The relationship between the different factors â because a pie 
chart compares parts of a whole, you need to note the different 
sizes of the sectors. This tells you how much each province 
contributes to the total GDP.
5. Look for anything that is unusual â for example, which is the 
largest piece of the pie (Gauteng) and which is the smallest piece 
of the pie (Northern Cape).
6. Now read the questions in activity 4.6.
 Activity 4.6
The following questions refer to Figure 4.5.1B on page 95.
1. Rank the top three provinces in terms of their contribution  
to the GDP from largest to smallest contribution. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
2. Give two reasons why the province ranked first in your  
answer in question 1 holds that position. 
(2 Ã 2 = 4)
3. The following questions refer to the province which  
contributes the least to the national GDP.
a) Name the province which contributes the least to the  
national GDP. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
b) Name the ocean current that flows alongside this  
province. 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
c) What impact does this ocean current have on the  
rainfall in this province? 
(1 Ã 2 = 2)
d) Explain how your answer in question c) affects the  
provinceâs contribution to the GDP. 
(2 Ã 2 = 4)
[16]
